unit_id:
B1 Preliminary English Test Vocabulary (PET):
Unit 1

senses.definition: How old someone is

examples.text: She is the same age as my sister.
What age do students take this test?

senses.definition: To become older over time

examples.text: Wine aged well in this room.
Do people age faster under stress?

senses.definition: Used to say how old someone is

examples.text: This class is for children aged 8 to 10.
They care for people aged over 65.
Is the game for kids aged under 12?

senses.definition: A very long time

examples.text: I haven’t seen him for ages.
It took ages to finish the homework.
Have you been waiting for ages?

senses.definition: To surprise someone very much
Feeling very surprised

examples.text: I was amazed by the news.
They are amazed at his progress.
Were you amazed by the answer?

check.question: How does someone feel if they are amazed?

senses.definition: Very surprising or very good
To tell people important news so everyone knows

examples.text: The school announces the results today.
When did they announce the decision?

senses.definition: A message that tells people important news

examples.text: There was an announcement on the train.
We listened carefully to the announcement.

senses.definition: To say you are sorry

examples.text: He apologises when he is late.
Did you apologise for the mistake?

senses.definition: Something you say or do to show you are sorry

examples.text: He gave her an apology after the mistake.

check.question: What is an apology?
choices: something you buy as a gift
something you say or do to show you are sorry

senses.definition: To start to be seen

examples.text: A rainbow appears after the rain.
Her name appeared on the list.
Did a problem appear during the test?

senses.definition: The way someone or something looks
To try to get a job, school placement, or course by filling in a form

examples.text: He applied for the course last week.
Did you apply for the program?

check.question: What does apply mean here?
choices: to try to get something by filling in a form

senses.definition: To put something onto something else

examples.text: The nurse applied pressure to the wound.
Did you apply cream to the skin?

senses.definition: A form you fill in to try to get something

examples.text: I filled out an application online.
Did you send the application yet?

senses.definition: To be angry and fight with someone using words

examples.text: Did they argue about the answer?

senses.definition: When people are angry and fight with each other using only words

examples.text: They had an argument last night.

senses.definition: Something you want to do or get

examples.text: Her aim is to pass the test.
The main aim of the class is learning.

senses.definition: To plan to do something

examples.text: The course aims to help students.
Do you aim to improve your English?

senses.definition: Cool air in a room or building (air conditioning) or the machine that makes it (air conditioner)

examples.text: The air conditioning is on in the classroom.
We bought a new air conditioner for the living room.
Is the air conditioning working today?

check.question: What is an air conditioner?
choices: the machine that makes the air cool

senses.definition: The part of a country’s army that uses planes

examples.text: He works in the air force.
The air force uses many planes.
Is the air force part of the army?

senses.definition: A company that flies people to different places

check.question: What is an airline?
choices: a place to wait for planes

senses.definition: A place where planes arrive and leave

examples.text: We arrived at the airport early.
Is the airport far from here?

senses.definition: A sound or device that warns people or wakes them up

examples.text: My alarm wakes me at six.

senses.definition: To make someone feel scared or worried
A book or collection for photos or music

examples.text: She showed me her photo album.
Did you listen to the album?

check.question: What is an album?
choices: a collection of photos or music

senses.definition: Almost the same as one another.
Living, not dead

examples.text: She felt alive again after resting.

senses.definition: Used to say something is OK or acceptable
senses.note: “All right” and “alright” mean the same thing. “All right” is more common in formal writing.

examples.text: It’s alright to ask for help.

check.question: What does all right / alright mean?

senses.definition: To say that something is OK to do

examples.text: The teacher allows phones in class.
They allowed us to leave early.

senses.definition: Very close to happening, but it hasn’t happened yet

examples.text: I almost fell asleep in class.
Did you almost miss the bus?

check.question: What does almost mean?
choices: very close, but it hasn’t happened

senses.definition: With no other people
In a way that other people can hear
All the letters from A to Z

examples.text: Please write your name using the English alphabet.
Do you know the whole alphabet?

senses.definition: Used to show a difference between two ideas

examples.text: Although it was raining, we went out.
She smiled although she was tired.
Did you go to the gym although it was raining?

senses.definition: Completely, or in total
The time from 12:00 at night to 12:00 at lunchtime

examples.text: Do you study in the a.m.?

senses.definition: Something you really want to do in the future

examples.text: Her ambition is to be a doctor.

check.question: What is an ambition?
choices: something you really want to do

senses.definition: A type of car or van that takes sick or hurt people to hospital

examples.text: She was taken to hospital in an ambulance.

check.question: What is an ambulance?
choices: a car or van for sick or hurt people

senses.definition: In the middle of a group of people or things
senses.note: Among and amongst mean the same thing. Among is more common and used everywhere. Amongst is used more in British English.

examples.text: She was sitting among her friends.
The house is hidden amongst the trees.
He felt nervous among so many people.

check.question: What does among / amongst mean?
choices: in the middle of a group

senses.definition: How much of something there is

examples.text: A large amount of homework was given.
The amount of rain surprised us.
The bills amounted to a lot of money.

senses.definition: Very old, from a long time ago
The part of the leg just above the foot

examples.text: She hurt her ankle playing football.

senses.definition: A date that remembers a special event from the past

check.question: What is an anniversary?
choices: a special date from the past

senses.definition: To tell people something important

examples.text: The teacher announced the test date.
They will announce the winner today.

senses.definition: Something important that is told to people

examples.text: We listened to the school announcement.

senses.definition: To make someone feel a little upset

examples.text: Does it annoy you when people are late?

senses.definition: Feeling worried or nervous about something

examples.text: She felt anxious before the test.
He is anxious about the results.

senses.definition: Any person at all, when it does not matter who

check.question: When do we use anybody?
choices: when we talk about one special person
when it does not matter who
when we talk about a place

senses.definition: Not now, but it was true in the past

examples.text: I don’t play that game anymore.

check.question: What does anymore mean?
choices: not now, but in the past

senses.definition: Any person at all
senses.note: Anyone means the same as anybody.

senses.definition: Any thing at all

examples.text: Is there anything I can help with?

senses.definition: Used when something happens even though there is a problem, or when changing the topic

examples.text: It was raining, but we went out anyway.
I didn’t like the movie. Anyway, let’s talk about school.
It’s raining, but are you coming anyway?

check.question: What does anyway do here?
choices: shows something happens despite a problem

senses.definition: In any place

examples.text: I can’t find my keys anywhere.

senses.definition: Separated, not together

examples.text: The two houses are far apart.

senses.definition: Used when one thing is not part of the group, or when one more thing is added

examples.text: Apart from English, she studies math.
Apart from the rain, the trip was great.
examples.tag: The trip was great, but the rain was bad

check.question: In the sentence “Everyone came apart from Tom,” what does it tell you?

senses.definition: One home inside a big building where many people live

examples.text: Their apartment is on the third floor.

check.question: What is an apartment?
choices: one home in a big building

senses.definition: A big building with many apartments inside

examples.text: That apartment building is very tall.
Many families live in the apartment building.

senses.definition: A program you use on a phone or computer

examples.text: I use this app every day.
Which app do you like most?

check.question: What is an app?
choices: a program on a phone or computer

senses.definition: A way of doing something

examples.text: This is a new approach to learning English.
Her approach to studying works well.

senses.definition: To move closer to someone or something

examples.text: He approached the teacher after class.
Did she approach the door quietly?

senses.definition: To say yes to something after thinking about it

examples.text: Did your parents approve the idea?

senses.definition: Close to a number. It can be a little less or a little more than the real number

examples.text: The test takes approximately one hour.
How many people were there approximately?

senses.definition: A person who plans how buildings will look and be built

examples.text: She wants to be an architect.
Did the architect visit the building site?

senses.definition: The way buildings look and are made

examples.text: The city is famous for its architecture.

senses.definition: A part of a place

examples.text: What area do you live in?

senses.definition: The part of the body from the shoulder to the hand
A chair with arms that you sit in

examples.text: The armchair is near the window.
Is the armchair comfortable to sit in?

check.question: What is an armchair?
choices: a chair you sit in with arms

senses.definition: A group of people who protect their country

examples.text: He joined the army last year.
Is the army large in this country?

senses.definition: Near something, in a circle, or about a number or time

examples.text: The children sat around the table.
There are shops around the school.
There were around 20 students in the class.

check.question: What does around help show here?

senses.definition: To plan something or put things in order

examples.text: She arranges the chairs before class.

check.question: What does arrange mean?
choices: to plan or put in order

senses.definition: A plan that has been made

examples.text: We talked about the seating arrangement.

senses.definition: To get to a place
A piece of writing in a newspaper, magazine, or online

examples.text: I read an article about animals.

senses.definition: Showing ideas in art, such as drawing, painting, or music

examples.text: She has an artistic style of drawing.

senses.definition: Sleeping
A person who helps someone at work

examples.text: She works as a shop assistant.

senses.definition: To go to an event, class, or place
Listening or looking carefully

examples.text: Are you giving this your full attention?

senses.definition: To stay away from something to stop a problem

examples.text: He avoided talking about the test.

senses.definition: Not sleeping
A prize given to someone for doing something well

examples.text: She won an award for her work.

senses.definition: To give someone a prize

examples.text: The school awards prizes each year.

senses.definition: Knowing about something

examples.text: I am aware of the problem.
She wasn’t aware of the rule.
Are you aware of the time?

senses.definition: Very bad

examples.text: He felt awful after the test.

senses.definition: Moving from front to back, or in the opposite direction

examples.text: Can you count backwards from ten?

senses.definition: Bags and suitcases used when traveling
The state of not falling to one side
To stay steady without falling

examples.text: Can you balance on the line?

senses.definition: A place where people keep money or get money

examples.text: I need to go to the bank today.
Is there a bank near here?

senses.definition: The bottom part of something, or the main part it stands on

examples.text: The statue has a wide base.
This chair has a strong base.

senses.definition: To use something as the main idea or reason

examples.text: The story is based on real events.
We base our answer on the text.
Is this idea based on facts?

check.question: What does base mean here?
choices: to use as the main idea

senses.definition: Simple and most important

examples.text: Do you know the basic rules?

senses.definition: A fight between groups of people

examples.text: They talked about the famous battle.

senses.definition: To try very hard to deal with a problem

examples.text: She battled to finish the work.
Are they battling the problem together?

senses.definition: A small round food from a plant
To accept or deal with something difficult

examples.text: Can you bear waiting a little longer?

senses.definition: To win against someone, or hit something again and again
Something that looks very nice or makes people feel good when they see it

examples.text: The beauty of the place surprised us.
She talked about the beauty of nature.
Do you see the beauty in simple things?
